{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2013}} {{good article}} {{Infobox Aviator |name= Albert Aubrey Koch |image= AAKochQANTAS.jpg|300px |caption= Captain Koch in Qantas uniform |birth_date= 2 October 1904 |death_date= {{death date and age|1975|6|21|1904|10|2|df=yes}} |birth_place= [[Ulverstone]], Tasmania |death_place= [[Mount Eliza, Victoria|Mt Eliza]], Victoria |nationality= Australian |known_for= Relief of [[Richard Archbold|Archbold]] Expedition
Shot down in [[History of Qantas|Qantas]] aircraft
[[Trans Australia Airlines]] executive |air_force= [[Royal Air Force]] (1927–30)
[[Royal Australian Air Force]] (1931–45) |service_years= 1926–1945 |rank=[[Flight Lieutenant]] |battles= Inter-war *Egypt and Palestine World War II *[[South West Pacific theatre of World War II|South West Pacific theatre]] |awards= [[Member of the Order of the British Empire]]}} '''Albert Aubrey (Aub) Koch''', [[Member of the Order of the British Empire|MBE]] (2 October 1904 – 21 June 1975) was a pioneering Australian military and civil pilot. He trained at [[RAAF Williams|Point Cook]] in 1926, and following graduation accepted a [[Officer (armed forces)|Short Service Commission]] in the [[Royal Air Force]] (RAF) as there were no places available in the [[Royal Australian Air Force]] (RAAF) at the time. After four years service in Egypt and Palestine, he returned to Australia and was commissioned into the Citizen Air Force, flying with [[No. 1 Squadron RAAF|No. 1 Squadron]] at [[RAAF Williams|Laverton]], where he gained flying instructor qualifications. Soon after, he was employed by [[Airlines of South Australia|Guinea Airways]] as an aircraft captain, and spent five years in [[Territory of Papua|Papua]] and [[New Guinea]] (PNG), gaining fame as the rescuer of the [[Richard Archbold|Archbold]] expedition. Koch was transferred to the RAAF Active Reserve upon going to PNG. He joined Qantas a year before World War II broke out, employed predominantly on the Singapore route. He was unfortunate to be the captain of the only Qantas aircraft known to be shot down during that war, when the [[Short Empire]] flying boat ''Corio'' was lost off Timor (''Circe'' disappeared in 1942, possibly also shot down, and ''Corinna'' was destroyed by enemy action on the water at [[Attack on Broome|Broome]], Western Australia). Post war he was recruited by [[Lester Brain]] at the formation of [[Trans Australia Airlines]] (TAA), specifically to be Senior Pilot [[Douglas DC4|DC4 Skymaster]]. At 45, he retired from active flying to become Inspector of Safety and Accidents, TAA. == Early career == Aubrey Koch was born at [[Ulverstone]], Tasmania on 2 October 1904, the son of R. W. Koch, later the Building Surveyor of Hobart, and Elinor (Burton) Koch. He was educated at [[The Friends' School, Hobart|Clemes College Hobart]], and began an Engineering Degree at the [[University of Tasmania]].{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article25215512|title=EXPEDITION RELIEVED IN NEW GUINEA|newspaper=[[The Mercury (Hobart)|The Mercury]] |location=Hobart|date=23 Jul 1936|accessdate=6 December 2011|page=9|publisher=National Library of Australia}} He was a keen rower, and was in the bow for the 1925 winning crew in the inter-varsity eights in Brisbane.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article66960582|title='VARSITY BOAT RACE|newspaper=[[The Advocate (Australia)|The Advocate]] |location=Burnie|date=8 Jun 1925|accessdate=6 December 2011|page=3|publisher=National Library of Australia}}{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article23822333|title=INTER-STATE 'VARSITY RACE|newspaper=[[The Mercury (Hobart)|The Mercury]] |location=Hobart|date=8 Jun 1925|accessdate=8 December 2011|page=10|publisher=National Library of Australia}} Aviation called, however, and he entered RAAF Point Cook for pilot training in 1926, graduating at the end of the year. He was one of six graduates from his course selected for a Short Service Commission in the RAF.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article29464522|title=NAVAL AND MILITARY|newspaper=[[The Mercury (Hobart)|The Mercury]] |location=Hobart|date=3 Nov 1926|accessdate=6 December 2011|page=11|publisher=National Library of Australia}} The others were L. C. L. Murray, E. H. Irving, G. Selk, F. Townsend, and C. H. A. Colman. [[File:216 Squadron RAF Vickers Victorias at Ismailia, Egypt, c1929 (A A Koch).jpg|thumb|300px|right|upright|No. 216 Squadron RAF Vickers Victorias at Ismailia (A. A. Koch)]] Koch was initially sent to England for training and assessment, where he flew the [[Avro 504]], the [[Armstrong Whitworth Siskin]], and the [[Bristol F.2 Fighter|Bristol Fighter]]. He then accepted a posting to the Middle East, and was attached to [[No. 208 Squadron RAF|No. 208 Army Cooperation Squadron]], RAF, at [[Heliopolis (Cairo suburb)|Heliopolis]], Egypt. There he was operational on the [[Bristol F.2 Fighter|Bristol Fighter]], and in August and September 1929 was involved in the suppression of the [[1929 Hebron massacre|Hebron riots]]. Whilst on leave in Australia in 1929, Koch met with Lieutenant Colonel [[Horace Brinsmead]], Controller of Civil Aviation, who advised him to gain experience on larger aircraft. However, his application for posting to a twin-engine squadron was refused. In May 1930, the Squadron re-equipped with [[Armstrong Whitworth Atlas]]. Koch was also allowed to convert to the [[Vickers Vimy]] at [[No. 216 Squadron RAF|No. 216 Squadron]], and flew as second pilot on [[Vickers Victoria]] aircraft. He returned to Australia at the end of 1930, arriving in [[Melbourne]] on 15 December.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article29825104|title=PERSONAL|newspaper=[[The Mercury (Hobart)|The Mercury]] |location=Hobart|date=15 Dec 1930|accessdate=6 December 2011|page=6|publisher=National Library of Australia}} In Egypt, Koch had continued his interest in rifle shooting{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article29824634|title=TASMANIAN RIFLEMAN ABROAD|newspaper=[[The Mercury (Hobart)|The Mercury]] |location=Hobart|date=11 Dec 1930|accessdate=8 December 2011|page=14|publisher=National Library of Australia}} and photography. Employment in public transport aviation was difficult to find in 1931, but Koch was able to continue flying with the Citizen Air Force at No. 1 Squadron, Laverton.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article29925569|title=NAVAL AND MILITARY|newspaper=[[The Mercury (Hobart)|The Mercury]] |location=Hobart|date=15 Dec 1930|accessdate=8 December 2011|page=4|publisher=National Library of Australia}}{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article24720002|title=NAVAL AND MILITARY|newspaper=[[The Mercury (Hobart)|The Mercury]] |location=Hobart|date=27 Jul 1932|accessdate=8 December 2011|page=9|publisher=National Library of Australia}} He flew as second pilot without pay for [[Australian National Airways (1930)|Australian National Airways]] in 1931,{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article24876153|title=PERSONAL|newspaper=[[The Mercury (Hobart)|The Mercury]] |location=Hobart|date=20 Jun 1933|accessdate=8 December 2011|page=8|publisher=National Library of Australia}} to gain experience, and was lucky not to be aboard the ill-fated [[Southern Cloud]], when family commitments prevented him taking his position. In mid-1933 he was appointed instructor with the Australian Aero Club, based at Essendon Aerodrome.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article24876153|title=PERSONAL|newspaper=[[The Mercury (Hobart)|The Mercury]] |location=Hobart|date=20 Jun 1933|accessdate=8 December 2011|page=8|publisher=National Library of Australia}} In November 1933, he was recruited by Guinea Airways as an aircraft captain, and was to spend the next five years in Papua and New Guinea. He flew the [[Junkers W 34]], the [[Junkers G 31]], and the [[Ford Trimotor|Ford Tri-Motor]] during this time, gaining much experience with sea operations when the W34 was float equipped. He gained some fame from his efforts to deliver supplies to the second (1936–37) [[Richard Archbold#1936-37 Expedition|Archbold Expedition]].{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article25216495|title=IN PAPUAN WILDS|newspaper=[[The Mercury (Hobart)|The Mercury]] |location=Hobart|date=21 Jul 1936|accessdate=8 December 2011|page=6|publisher=National Library of Australia}}{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article25215512|title=EXPEDITION RELIEVED IN NEW GUINEA|newspaper=[[The Mercury (Hobart)|The Mercury]] |location=Hobart|date=23 Jul 1936|accessdate=8 December 2011|page=9|publisher=National Library of Australia}} The expedition had become isolated when its own aircraft was accidentally destroyed in [[Port Moresby]] harbour, and was thought to be camped in the Blucher Mountains near the headwaters of the [[Strickland River]], low on supplies and without fuel for its generators. Koch, operating out of [[Mt Hagen]] in a Ford fitted with long range tanks, found the party and resupplied it by parachute with food and gasoline.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article41746989|title=RELIEF BY PLANE|newspaper=[[The Cairns Post]] |location=Cairns|date=20 Jul 1936|accessdate=26 April 2012|page=6|publisher=National Library of Australia}}{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article41748505|title=PAPUAN NOTES|newspaper=[[The Cairns Post]] |location=Cairns|date=25 Jul 1936|accessdate=26 April 2012|page=6|publisher=National Library of Australia}} Among his many photographs taken during this period are several of the last known days of [[Amelia Earhart]] at Lae aerodrome."The Earhart Project" http://tighar.org/Projects/Earhart/Archives/Research/Bulletins/27_LaeGallery/27_LaeGallery.html He married Clarice Grant on 1 June 1933, in [[Melbourne]];Victorian Registry of Births, Deaths and Marriages, registration #4621, Clarice Edna Grant/Albert Aubrey Koch the couple were to have a daughter and two sons.{{cite news |url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/29205518|title=THE SOCIAL ROUND|newspaper=[[The Mercury (Hobart)|The Mercury]] |location=Hobart|date=16 February 1938|accessdate=8 May 2012|page=4S|publisher=National Library of Australia}}New South Wales Registry of Births, Deaths and Marriages, #44858/455 David Aubrey Koch, 31 October 1939 == World War II == Koch finally achieved his ambition of joining what was then known as [[History of Qantas|Qantas Empire Airways]] (QEA) with an appointment on 4 July 1938. The Singapore service commenced on 2 August 1938 (the westbound service was "officially" opened on 4 August). In the arcane language of QEA, he was promoted from "Extra Mate" to "Senior Mate" in October 1940. This allowed him to fly as relief Captain on the Singapore service. He was soon promoted to "Master", and in June 1943 to "Extra Master". QEA was intimately involved in the war effort almost from its beginning, and in late 1940 was contracted to fly 19 [[Consolidated PBY Catalina|PBY5 Catalinas]] from Honolulu to Australia on behalf of the RAAF. By a convenience, the crews were regarded as civilians (to meet American diplomatic niceties) for this operation, but on other RAAF contracts, particularly to combat zones, they were seen as serving in the RAAF Reserve. Brain, Koch and [[Patrick Gordon Taylor|P. G .Taylor]] flew the final delivery flight of the Catalina ferry, arriving in Sydney on 24 October 1941, for the first time via [[Suva]], Fiji. This crew determined to commemorate their mission by flying the first [[Airmail]] delivery between Fiji and Australia, and to that end they had a large number of "[[First day of issue|First Day Covers]]" (but without Airmail stamps) endorsed by the Suva Post Office prior to departure, and by the Sydney Post Office on arrival (some examples of what became collector's items are held by the [[Qantas Founders Outback Museum|Qantas Museum]]). They also transported 200 pounds weight of ordinary mail on behalf of the Fiji postal authorities.Bennett-Bremner, ''Front Line Airline,'' p. 26 This plan led to a serious contretemps with [[Pan American World Airways|Pan American]], which had the contract to convey the air mail from Fiji but was not due to start operations until 9 November 1941. [[File:Short Empire S23 Capella (A A Koch).jpg|thumb|300px|right|upright|Imperial Airways Short Empire ''Capella'' c. 1940 (A. A. Koch)]] Koch returned to the East Indies operation, and on 30 January 1942, when in command of ''Corio'', he was [[1942 Qantas Short Empire shoot-down|shot down]] off Timor by seven Japanese [[Mitsubishi A6M Zero|Zeros]] whilst carrying out a relief flight to [[Surabaya]], Dutch East Indies. Of the eighteen people on board, five survived.Gunn, ''Challenging Horizons, QANTAS 1939–1954'' p. 49 Koch was wounded by gunfire in the left leg and left arm, and broke his right leg in the subsequent crash landing.Bennett-Bremner, ''Front Line Airline,'' p. 55 Despite the injuries, he swam about five miles to the shore where he was looked after by local people, until the Dutch Navy found the survivors some days later, and rescued them with a [[Dornier Do 24|Dornier]] flying boat. Some three weeks later, he was in Darwin hospital on the day of the [[Bombing of Darwin|first Japanese raid]] on Darwin. By good fortune, the QEA flying boat ''Camilla'' survived the raid, and Koch was flown to Sydney for treatment.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article8234215|title=JAPS. KNEW WHERE TO STRIKE|newspaper=[[The Argus (Australia)|The Argus]] |location=Melbourne|date=23 Feb 1942|accessdate=8 December 2011|page=3|publisher=National Library of Australia}} He was unfortunate again on 22 April 1943 when, in command of ''Camilla'' on an RAAF contract involving the transport of military personnel to Port Moresby, he found himself unable to proceed due to bad weather, and was forced to attempt a night landing on the open ocean when off the coast of New Guinea. Due largely to the inexperience of his co-pilot, the aircraft broke up on landing, and 13 out of the 31 people on board did not survive. Koch spent about 18 hours in the sea before being rescued at the chance passage of a local steamer.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article11332017|title=SURVIVORS WERE l8 HOURS IN SEA BEFORE RESCUE|newspaper=[[The Argus (Australia)|The Argus]] |location=Melbourne|date=23 Feb 1942|accessdate=9 December 2011|page=3|publisher=National Library of Australia}}Bennett-Bremner, ''Front Line Airline,'' p.166 A. B. Corbett, the [[Airservices Australia#History|Director-General of Civil Aviation]], recommended to his Minister that in view of the circumstances no Court of Inquiry be held—in effect Koch was exonerated.Corbett, ''Report on Loss of QANTAS Empire Flying Boat VH-ADU.'' == Post-war career == In 1946, the Australian Government determined to nationalise commercial air operations in the belief that air transport was primarily a public service, but was prevented from doing so by a High Court decision. It therefore formed a government airline to compete with the private carriers, which was to be administered by the Australian National Airways Commission, and would operate as [[Trans Australia Airlines]] (TAA). Lester Brain was headhunted from Qantas and was appointed General Manager of the new airline. One of his first appointments was that of Captain Aubrey Koch to be Senior Pilot DC4 Skymaster.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article22323886|title=AIRLINES APPOINTMENT |newspaper=[[The Argus (Australia)|The Argus]] |location=Melbourne|date=31 Jul 1946|accessdate=9 December 2011|page=3|publisher=National Library of Australia}} Koch remained in this role for four years, retiring from active flying in September 1950 with in excess of 17,000 flying hours, due to disabilities developed from his war injuries, and taking up the role of Inspector of Air Safety.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article26725597|title=VETERAN PILOT LEAVES AIR FOR GROUND JOB |newspaper=[[The Mercury (Hobart)|The Mercury]] |location=Hobart|date=5 Sep 1950|accessdate=9 December 2011|page=8|publisher=National Library of Australia}} In June 1955 he was appointed a Member of the Civil Division of the Most Excellent [[Order of the British Empire]], the citation being: "In recognition of Captain Koch's long and distinguished service to civil aviation in Australia." He finally retired in June 1961, and settled at [[Mount Eliza, Victoria|Mt Eliza]], Victoria, where he died on 21 June 1975.''Aircraft,'' July 1975 Issue, p. 44 == Notes == {{Reflist|30em}} == References == * {{cite book|last=Bennett-Bremner| first=E|year=1944| title=Front Line Airline: The War Story of Qantas Empire Airways Ltd | location=Sydney, NSW| publisher=Angus and Robertson Ltd}} * {{cite book|last=Gunn| first=John|year=1990| title=Challenging Horizons: QANTAS 1939–1954 | location=St Lucia, QLD| publisher=University of Queensland Press |isbn=0-70-222205-4}} * Corbett, A.B. ( 11 Oct 1943) Director-General of Civil Aviation ''Report on Loss of QANTAS Empire Flying Boat VH-ADU, near Port Moresby, 22/4/43.'' {{DEFAULTSORT:Koch, Aubrey}} [[Category:1904 births]] [[Category:1975 deaths]] [[Category:Australian aviators]] [[Category:Members of the Order of the British Empire]] [[Category:Royal Air Force officers]] [[Category:Royal Australian Air Force officers]]
